awd_titl_txt: Processes controlling the shape and evolution of sandy spits along coastlines
awd_abstract_narration:
Coastal regions are often highly developed, and sustained rates of change of the position of the shoreline can be on the order of meters per year, substantially faster than many other landscape processes that affect human development and infrastructure. Despite a long history of the study of the historic and geologic evolution of these dynamic landforms, it is still not possible to arrive at quantitative prediction of shoreline change. This project will take a major step forward by investigating the controls on the growth and shape of the coastal feature known as a sand spit. These curved accumulations of sand are common features of many coastlines. This project will focus on outer Cape Cod, one of the most recognizable of these features, to conduct field measurements and develop a sophisticated numerical model that documents the evolution of this sand spit. This project will interact directly with the population and decision-makers affected by coastal change by developing a short course and informational materials about coastal processes on Cape Cod and similar settings.

This research will investigate how waves affect spit evolution and the sensitivity of spit-headland systems to wave climate changes over both long (millennial) and short (decadal) temporal scales.  Quantifying these constraints over historic and geologic time intervals will facilitate a stronger understanding of the evolution of the Cape Cod and Islands region that is applicable to coastal settings over a wide area. The project will use numerical modeling, geologic investigations, and analysis of historic change to 1) identify the controls on spit shape and recurving, 2) investigate how wave climate affects spit development and shoreline evolution, 3) determine patterns of shoreline change in the Cape Cod region over historic (10-100 years), and 4) reconstruct the development of Cape Cod spits over longer (100 - >1000 years) periods.

por.por_cntn:
Sandy spits are ubiquitous coastal features, depositional landforms often developing at the downdrift end of bluffs and other headlands. Some of the most dynamic landforms in nature, spit shorelines can retreat at rates in excess of meters per year, even as the deposition occurs at the downdrift end. Despite a long history of study of the historic and geologic evolution of these dynamic landforms, a fundamental quantitative understanding of spit evolution has yet to be presented. This project used numerical modeling to develop improved theoretical understanding of spit evolution. These model results were then used to better understand shoreline change of the Cape Cod, MA, region over historic and geologic timeframes. These results help us better understand coastal change hazards are applicable to sandy shorelines globally, and in particular across the US East coast.


Intellectual Merit: This project refined our understanding of the controls on shoreline evolution, providing a more thorough understanding of coastline evolution and therefore changing coastlines in the following ways:


1) Refine our theoretical understanding of the controls upon spit shape and recurving, including the effect of headlands and longer-term changes in wave climate. Numerical modeling was used to simulate spit growth off of headlands, leading to a conceptual model of spit evolution (figure attached), whereby sediment eroding from a headland feeds a spit, which contains a retreating "neck" and a growing "hook." How these points move over time is determined by headland characteristics and wave climate. Modeling results suggest that bluff height and composition play a less significant role in spit growth than previously hypothesized. Models were used to also understand how spits are resistant to breaching.


2) Investigate shoreline wave climate variables and shoreline change for natural examples over historic timescales (10-100 years). Long-term (30+ year) wave climate analysis, combined with bluff elevation data, was used to make predictions of shoreline change. These were compared to USGS measured historical shorelines extracted from GIS to better understand the evolution of the Cape Cod shoreline.


3) Collect and analyze sedimentologic data to refine geologic (100-1000's years) models of the evolution of spits on Cape Cod and Islands and compare this evolution to natural examples. We collected over 20 miles of Ground-Penetrating Radar (GPR) data along the Provincetown hook. The GPR data revealed that, in contrast to previous hypotheses, the extension of the spit was a continuous process. This data was sued to collect deep percussion cores to better analyze sedimentology and the growth history of the cape.


Broader Impacts: The goal for this project was to present concepts of coastal change to an audience of decision-makers and stakeholders. The research results, as well as discussion of broader concepts such as coastal resiliency, were presented to local stakeholder groups and residents, including public presentation at the Cape Cod National Seashore. The lead PI also was a member of the Town of Falmouth Coastal Resiliency Action Committee, providing knowledge of coastal change hazards (studied as part of this project), helping to coordinate several coastal vulnerability studies as well as a final report to the Falmouth Board of Select. The PI also discussed coastal processes with the press, including WBUR, Guardian US, and Nasa Image of the Day. The project has provided training to two PhD and two undergraduate Guest Students The field crew included 6 young scientists, 5 of whom are women. One of these field assistants is now enrolled in the WHOI/MIT Joint Program pursuing a PhD.
